text: IBM X-Force Incident Response and Intelligence Services (IRIS) responds to security incidents across the globe.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: During a recent incident response investigation, our team identified new attacks by the financially motivated attack group ITG08, also known as FIN6.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: ITG08 is an organized cybercrime gang that has been active since 2015, mostly targeting point-of-sale (POS) machines in brick-and-mortar retailers and companies in the hospitality sector in the U.S. and Europe.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: More recently, the group has been observed targeting e-commerce environments by injecting malicious code into online checkout pages of compromised websites — a technique known as online skimming — thereby stealing payment card data transmitted to the vendor by unsuspecting customers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Based on our investigation and analysis of its adversarial tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs), we believe ITG08 is actively attacking multinational organizations, targeting specific employees with spear phishing emails advertising fake job advertisements and repeatedly deploying the More_eggs JScript backdoor malware (aka Terra Loader, SpicyOmelette).
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This tool, a TTP observed in ITG08 attacks since 2018, is sold on the dark web by an underground malware-as-a-service (MaaS) provider.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Attackers use it to create, expand and cement their foothold in compromised environments.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Past campaigns by ITG08 using the More_eggs backdoor were last reported in February 2019.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In the campaign we investigated, the attackers employed additional TTPs historically associated with ITG08, including the use of Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to automate the remote execution of PowerShell scripts, PowerShell commands with base64 encoding, and Metasploit and PowerShell to move laterally and deploy malware.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Lastly, the attackers used Comodo code-signing certificates several times during the course of the campaign.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Many of the above TTPs are not unique to ITG08, but collectively, and with the use of More_eggs, strengthen the link to this group.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Let’s take a closer look at ITG08’s TTPs that are relevant to the campaign we investigated, starting with its spear phishing and intrusion tactics and covering information on its use of the More_eggs backdoor.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Please note that Visa has attributed the use of this backdoor to FIN6 in attacks that took place in 2018.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Further linking the activity with the same threat actor, several of the network indicators and TTPs we encountered in this case — including the use of fake job advertisements as a lure in spear phishing — overlap with those reported earlier in 2019 by both Visa and Proofpoint researchers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: ITG08’s TTPs in compromising targeted organizations follow the typical framework for APT attacks.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The following sections go over the steps taken by the attackers to gain an initial foothold and persist on the victimized organization’s networks.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: To gain access to victim environments, the threat actor began by targeting handpicked employees using LinkedIn messaging and email, advertising fake jobs to lure recipients into checking into the supposed offers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In one case, we uncovered evidence indicating that the attacker had established communication with a victim via email and convinced them to click on a Google Drive URL purporting to contain an attractive job advert.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Once clicked, the URL displayed the message, “Online preview is not available,” then presented a second URL leading to a compromised or rogue domain, where the victim could download the payload under the guise of a job description:
Figure 1: Link provided in spear phishing email to an employee
That URL, in turn, downloaded a ZIP file containing a malicious Windows Script File (WSF) that initiated the infection routine of the More_eggs backdoor:
Figure 2: Final landing page that downloads a malicious file
Based on file system artifacts examined during our investigation, the ZIP file and WSF files were deleted upon a successful malware infection, likely in an attempt to prevent researchers from recovering the original files from the filesystem.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The filesystem, however, contained evidence of a nonmalicious decoy document dropped to the disk drive during the spear phishing attacks.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The spear phishing attacks unfortunately led to initial compromise and the installation of the More_eggs JScript backdoor, which established a reverse shell connection to the attacker’s command-and-control (C&C) infrastructure.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Additional capabilities of the More_eggs malware include the download and execution of files and scripts and running commands using cmd.exe.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: X-Force IRIS determined that the More_eggs backdoor later downloaded additional files, including a signed binary shellcode loader and a signed Dynamic Link Library (DLL), as described below, to create a reverse shell and connect to a remote host.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The shellcode loader was observed on one infected device as updater.exe with the Metasploit-style service name APTYnDS1ABEuUHEA, indicating that it was installed as a service.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once the attackers established a foothold on the network, they employed WMI and PowerShell techniques to perform network reconnaissance and move laterally within the environment.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This type of method, called living off the land, can often blend with legitimate system administration activities, which can make it challenging for security controls to detect.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The attackers used this technique to remotely install a Metasploit reverse TCP stager on select systems, subsequently spawning a Meterpreter session and Mimikatz.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Meterpreter is a payload component in the Metasploit Framework that uses in-memory DLL injection, which can lead to a compromise by malware or any malicious code/commands.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that allows attackers to extract credentials from volatile memory.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Stolen credentials are usually leveraged to facilitate privilege escalation and further lateral movement through the compromised environment.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once the Metasploit reverse TCP stager executed, it downloaded and loaded a second stage Meterpreter DLL into memory, allowing the attacker to spawn a Meterpreter session via a handler and initiate the loading of extensions, such as Mimikatz.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In addition to the More_eggs malware, the attacker leveraged in-memory attacks by injecting malicious code, in this case Mimikatz, into legitimate system processes.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: To cement their foothold and add persistence throughout the compromised environment, X-Force IRIS uncovered evidence that the attacker had selected several additional devices on which to install the More_eggs backdoor, creating redundancy in ways to get back into the network.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: ITG08 remotely connected to these devices using PowerShell and WMI and downloaded and executed a DLL file, subsequently installing More_eggs on the device without dropping the nonmalicious decoy document.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: A recently rising attack tool in ITG08 campaigns has been the More_eggs JScript backdoor.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: But while it was recently identified with ITG08 activity, the More_eggs backdoor is apparently developed and sold through an underground MaaS provider.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This vendor not only supplies the backdoor malware, but also offers related technical services, such as preparing the network infrastructure to download More_eggs-related files and furnishing resources for C&C purposes.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In addition to More_eggs, the same underground vendor is also responsible for producing the signed DLL described below, which creates a reverse shell (ReverseShell Executable).
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
We based this assessment on code similarities between the DLL and other samples created by the same vendor, including the DLL that drops the More_eggs backdoor.
Figure 3: Network indicators revealing the use of an underground MaaS vendor selling More_eggs and malicious infrastructure services
After a successful phishing attack in which users have opened emails and browsed to malicious links, ITG08 attackers install the More_eggs JScript backdoor on user devices alongside several other malware components.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The process begins with the consistent execution of a malicious DLL using the legitimate regsvr32.exe Windows Utility.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once executed, the DLL is deleted from the system and its components are dropped to the system.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Before being deleted, the DLL executes a string decoding routine that is designed to execute for about a minute, spiking central processing unit (CPU) usage for the regsvr32.exe process.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Once the strings are decoded, the More_eggs components are decrypted, dropped to the system
(normally in the %APPDATA%\Microsoft\ or %ProgramData%\Microsoft\ directories) and executed.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
The observed strings appearing like HEX-encoded strings are shown below:
Figure 4: Sample encoded and decoded strings
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
The More_eggs dropper DLL creates the following components on the infected device (further detail on each component in the chart follows in the next section):
Figure 5: Components created by DLL
msxsl.exe is executed by the script file A70613FF7F5DE98.txt, which is obfuscated as shown below:
Figure 6: Obfuscated script file A70613FF7F5DE98.txt
The use of msxsl.exe is a known tactic to execute malicious code and bypass application whitelisting.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The deobfuscated command is built as follows:
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once the above command is executed, the More_eggs JScript loader 5795C3AC7F57F.txt will deobfuscate the embedded More_eggs JScript.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: A sample loader is shown below.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
The start of the XSL file:
The end of the XSL file:
The “select” value within the template tag points to the function in the msxsl:script tag, which will execute when the msxsl.exe command is run.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The JScript loader file is highly obfuscated and decodes the More_eggs backdoor in a variety of ways, including RC4 decryption.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The analysis in this section details the functionality of More_eggs backdoor samples specific to this investigation, so please bear in mind that the same malware can be deployed differently in other campaigns and by alternate attackers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The core functionality of the samples analyzed in this campaign remained the same as described by previous researchers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: We aimed to add additional detail about the inner workings of the malware, including its C&C communications flow, its filesystem activity, and some encryption and encoding schemes used by the samples we analyzed.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The More_eggs backdoor is executed entirely in memory, never touching the filesystem in an unencrypted state.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Notable configuration data is hardcoded and includes its C&C server address, malware version number and an Rkey value, which is believed to identify campaign perpetrators to the vendor:
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Upon initial execution, the backdoor checks its environment to determine whether it is running with administrative or user privileges, and if proper components are present on the system.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: To check the user’s privilege level on the newly infected device, it attempts to read the registry key HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-19\Environment\TEMP; a successful read means it is running with administrative privileges, and the backdoor builds the path %ProgramData%\Microsoft.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If it is not running with administrative privileges, the path %AppData%\Microsoft is used.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The More_eggs backdoor obtains the username and computer name of the infected device, and if running with privileges, it reads the following registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Notepad\<computername>.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If not running with privileges, it reads the key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Notepad\<username> instead.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The data in these Windows registry keys is expected to be a comma-separated list of files with no extension.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The .txt extension is appended to the name by the backdoor.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If these files exist along with msxsl.exe in the proper location, either %ProgramData%\Microsoft or %AppData%\Microsoft, the malware’s execution continues.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once the environment is checked, the backdoor will check for network connectivity by sending an HTTP GET request to hxxp://www.w3[.]org/1999/XSL/Format, ensuring the response is “This is another XSL namespace\n.”
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If the connection is successful, the backdoor builds a string formatted with “|<random-value>|”.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The random value is between 8 and 32 bytes long, RC4-encrypted, basE91 encoded, and subsequently sent to the C&C in an HTTP POST request.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The RC4 key used is generated from the Rkey variable value:
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
POST HTTP/1.1
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-us
User-Agent:
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
[User agent string]
Content-Length: 36
Host:
6R+#9fWCy)htQSo4:H9&JSMTx|X[OEKj^gXE
The C&C response is expected to be between 8 and 32 bytes long, nothing is done with the server response.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
The random value acts as a handshake between the backdoor and the C&C, and during failure of any of the above, More_eggs sends an HTTP GET request to 8.8.8.8 with a pseudorandom 8 to 32-byte URI.
Figure 11: HTTP GET request to 8.8.8.8

text: The past two years have borne witness to the increasing collaboration between organized cybercrime groups to avoid duplication of efforts and maximize profits.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Although this collaboration has primarily occurred between gangs developing and distributing well-known banking Trojans, such as Emotet, TrickBot and IcedID, it does not stop there.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In a new and dangerous twist to this trend, IBM X-Force Incident Response and Intelligence Services (IRIS) research believes that the elite cybercriminal threat actor ITG08, also known as FIN6, has partnered with the malware gang behind one of the most active Trojans — TrickBot — to use TrickBot’s new malware framework dubbed “Anchor” against organizations for financial profit.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The Anchor malware framework itself is not new and its origins date back to at least 2018.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: It appears to be tightly connected to TrickBot and is likely programmed by the same malware authors that work on TrickBot.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Cybersecurity firms SentinelOne and Cybereason have published reports in recent months describing Anchor as new malware developed by the TrickBot gang for use in targeted attacks against enterprises, including a new PowerShell-based backdoor called PowerTrick.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: ITG08/FIN6 is an organized cybercrime gang that has been active since 2015, primarily targeting point-of-sale (POS) machines in brick-and-mortar retailers and companies in the hospitality sector across the U.S. and Europe.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: TrickBot is a banking Trojan that emerged in 2016 and has since grown to be one of the top, and most sophisticated, Trojans being used by organized cybercrime gangs believed to be hailing out of Russia.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In the past six months, the Anchor backdoor malware, which includes a variant that communicates over DNS (Anchor_DNS), has been used in targeted attacks on enterprise networks — including POS systems — following initial infection by the TrickBot Trojan.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The way organizations are being attacked ties with typical ITG08 activity reported throughout the past few years.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Through connecting our own findings with information from other security research reports, X-Force IRIS has determined that the threat actor ITG08 has partnered with the TrickBot gang to use that group’s PowerTrick and Anchor backdoor malware for attacks on high-profile targets.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: This post provides more detail on that connection.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
Visa Public 
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption  
FIN6 Cybercrime Group Expands Threat to eCommerce 
Merchants 
FIN6 is a financially motivated threat actor group in operation since at least 2015.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The group has 
compromised multiple point-of-sale (POS) environments using the TRINITY POS (aka FrameworkPOS) 
malware.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In September 2017, forensic investigations of several undisclosed entities revealed evidence that 
FIN6 actors changed to target card-not-present (CNP) data when they could not deploy their malware in 
the POS environment.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Evidence shows that FIN6 injected malicious code into the merchants’ eCommerce 
environment, placing skimming malware on the victims’ checkout pages.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Based on Visa Payment Fraud 
Disruption’s (PFD) analysis of eCommerce compromises throughout 2018, FIN6’s focus on the CNP 
environment has only amplified, suggesting that the cybercrime group has fully incorporated 
targeting CNP environments into their criminal methodology.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The majority of eCommerce compromises reported in 2018 involved direct targeting of vulnerabilities 
within the eCommerce website itself.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
As one of the more sophisticated groups targeting eCommerce 
merchants, FIN6 brings their POS compromise approach to the emerging threat landscape of CNP 
breaches.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
FIN6 targets companies, using phishing emails in an attempt to infect the targeted victim’s 
network.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: The actors then move through the network to identify POS and eCommerce environments.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
PFD 
assesses that the increased focus of a sophisticated cybercrime group, such as FIN6, on eCommerce 
environments is a broader representation of the overall cybercriminal focus on the CNP space.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
At the end of 2018, Visa Payment Intelligence analysts discovered that FIN6 actors targeted multiple high 
value eCommerce merchants with malicious documents that contained links to a malicious server that 
allowed the execution of PowerShell scripts, granting the attackers direct access to the merchants’ 
networks.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The PowerShell scripts were only present in memory, and did not download additional files to 
the user’s machine, making it difficult for the victim to detect.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The FIN6 actors were able to utilize this 
access to move through the merchant’s networks to access the eCommerce environment, and specifically 
the payment servers.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
A full investigation of these compromises show that the FIN6 actors specifically 
targeted the eCommerce networks and did not exploit them opportunistically.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Visa Public 
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption  
Figure 1 - FIN6 eCommerce Attack Flow 
Initial Compromise 
FIN6 employs a multitude of tactics within the initial phase of their operations.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In the most recent 
compromises attributed to FIN6, forensic investigators identified the use of malicious documents to infect 
victims with malware known as More_Eggs (aka Terra Loader) that is used to launch malicious scripts on 
the infected machine.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Maintain Access 
FIN6 establishes a foothold within a victim’s environment by leveraging various payloads, such as 
components of the Metasploit Framework (e.g., Meterpreter, JSPSPY and CmdSQL), or through a 
Visa Public 
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption  
specialized version of the AMMYY remote administration tool (RAT) known as FlawedAmmyy.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In the most 
recent cases, attackers then establish persistent access to the victim’s network using Meterpreter related 
code, allowing the attackers to maintain a remote connection to the infected system.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Internal Reconnaissance 
FIN6 uses legitimate publicly available tools to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
During the reconnaissance phase, the actors gather information on systems running SQL Database Server 
instances and dump schemas for multiple databases and SQL user accounts.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The actors also target 
network credentials using a malware family known as Stealer One (see below in the section Technical 
Analysis and Indicators of Compromise).
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Additionally, FIN6 employs legitimate administrative tools, such as: 
•  Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool (osql.exe) 
•  Query Express (a free, portable graphical SQL client) 
•
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
AdFind (a free command-line tool for querying Active Directory)  
•
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
ProcDump (a Microsoft SysInternals command-line utility used to perform analysis of running 
Escalate Privileges 
Once FIN6’s accesses are established with preferred backdoors, they use additional public utilities, such as 
Windows Credentials Editor and Metasploit-related tools, for privilege escalation and credential harvesting.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Move Laterally/Maintain Presence 
Capitalizing on data acquired via internal reconnaissance, FIN6 relies on credentials stolen from various 
systems (e.g. usernames and password hashes) for lateral movement.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Investigations show that FIN6 relies 
on PowerShell scripts and Meterpreter based shells to maintain access to and move laterally through the 
network (see below in the section Technical Analysis and Indicators of Compromise).
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Visa Public 
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption  
Technical Analysis and Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)  
Malicious Files – Stealer One 
Stealer One is a credential stealer, first observed by industry forensic investigators in March 2017.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The 
malware targets a variety of applications, including email clients, web browsers, FTP clients, and other file 
transfer utilities.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:

Institute recurring checks in local networks for IOCs provided in this report.

Standard (PCI DSS) requires that all system components and software are protected from known 
vulnerabilities by installing security patches.

Council (PCI SSC) website for more information.

professional or service provider with a reputation of security to secure the eCommerce 
environment.

taken by the company you hire.

on another webpage hosted by that checkout solution, separate from the merchant’s site.

text: Targeted ransomware incidents have brought a threat of disruptive and destructive attacks to organizations across industries and geographies.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye Mandiant Threat Intelligence has previously documented this threat in our investigations of trends across ransomware incidents, FIN6 activity, implications for OT networks, and other aspects of post-compromise ransomware deployment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Since November 2019, we’ve seen the MAZE ransomware being used in attacks that combine targeted ransomware use, public exposure of victim data, and an affiliate model.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Malicious actors have been actively deploying MAZE ransomware since at least May 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The ransomware was initially distributed via spam emails and exploit kits before later shifting to being deployed post-compromise.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Multiple actors are involved in MAZE ransomware operations, based on our observations of alleged users in underground forums and distinct tactics, techniques, and procedures across Mandiant incident response engagements.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Actors behind MAZE also maintain a public-facing website where they post data stolen from victims who refuse to pay an extortion fee.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The combination of these two damaging intrusion outcomes—dumping sensitive data and disrupting enterprise networks—with a criminal service makes MAZE a notable threat to many organizations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This blog post is based on information derived from numerous Mandiant incident response engagements and our own research into the MAZE ecosystem and operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant Threat Intelligence will be available to answer questions on the MAZE ransomware threat in a May 21 webinar.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: We are aware of more than 100 alleged MAZE victims reported by various media outlets and on the MAZE website since November 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These organizations have been primarily based in North America, although victims spanned nearly every geographical region.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Nearly every industry sector including manufacturing, legal, financial services, construction, healthcare, technology, retail, and government has been impacted demonstrating that indiscriminate nature of these operations (Figure 1).
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant identified multiple Russian-speaking actors who claimed to use MAZE ransomware and were seeking partners to fulfill different functional roles within their teams.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Additional information on these actors is available to Mandiant Intelligence subscribers.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: A panel used to manage victims targeted for MAZE ransomware deployment has a section for affiliate transactions.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This activity is consistent with our assessment that MAZE operates under an affiliate model and is not distributed by a single group.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Under this business model, ransomware developers will partner with other actors (i.e. affiliates) who are responsible for distributing the malware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In these scenarios, when a victim pays the ransom demand, the ransomware developers receive a commission.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Direct affiliates of MAZE ransomware also partner with other actors who perform specific tasks for a percentage of the ransom payment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This includes partners who provide initial access to organizations and pentesters who are responsible for reconnaissance, privilege escalation and lateral movement—each of which who appear to work on a percentage-basis.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, in some cases, actors may be hired on a salary basis (vs commission) to perform specific tasks such as determining the victim organization and its annual revenues.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This allows for specialization within the cyber criminal ecosystem, ultimately increasing efficiency, while still allowing all parties involved to profit.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: MAZE ransomware was initially distributed directly via exploit kits and spam campaigns through late 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: For example, in November 2019, Mandiant observed multiple email campaigns delivering Maze ransomware primarily to individuals at organizations in Germany and the United States, although a significant number of emails were also delivered to entities in Canada, Italy, and South Korea.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails used tax, invoice, and package delivery themes with document attachments or inline links to documents which download and execute Maze ransomware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: On November 6 and 7, a Maze campaign targeting Germany delivered macro-laden documents using the subject lines “Wichtige informationen uber Steuerruckerstattung” and “1&1 Internet AG - Ihre Rechnung 19340003422 vom 07.11.19” (Figure 3).
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Recipients included individuals at organizations in a wide range of industries, with the Financial Services, Healthcare, and Manufacturing sectors being targeted most frequently.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails were sent using a number of malicious domains created with the registrant address gladkoff1991@yandex.ru.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: On November 8, a campaign delivered Maze primarily to Financial Services and Insurance organizations located in the United states.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails originated from a compromised or spoofed account and contained an inline link to download a Maze executable payload.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: On November 18 and 19, a Maze campaign targeted individuals operating in a range of industries in the United States and Canada with macro documents using phone bill and package delivery themes (Figure 4 and Figure 5).
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails used the subjects “Missed package delivery” and "Your AT&T wireless bill is ready to view" and were sent using a number of malicious domains with the registrant address abusereceive@hitler.rocks.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, this registrant address was also used to create multiple Italian-language domains towards the end of November 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Actors using MAZE have increasingly shifted to deploying the ransomware post-compromise.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This methodology provides an opportunity to infect more hosts within a victim’s environment and exfiltrate data, which is leveraged to apply additional pressure on organizations to pay extortion fees.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, in at least some cases, the actors behind these operations charge an additional fee, in addition to the decryption key, for the non-release of stolen data.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Although the high-level intrusion scenarios preceding the distribution of MAZE ransomware are broadly similar, there have been notable variations across intrusions that suggest attribution to distinct teams.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Even within these teams, the cyber criminals appear to be task-oriented meaning that one operator is not responsible for the full lifecycle.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The following sections highlight the TTPs seen in a subset of incidents and serve to illustrate the divergence that may occur due to the fact that numerous, disparate actors are involved in different phases of these operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, the time between initial compromise to encryption has also been widely varied, from weeks to many months.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: There are few clear patterns for intrusion vector across analyzed MAZE ransomware incidents.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This is consistent with our observations of multiple actors who use MAZE soliciting partners with network access.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text:
The following are a sample of observations from several Mandiant incident response engagements:
The use of legitimate credentials and broad distribution of BEACON across victim environments appear to be consistent approaches used by actors to establish their foothold in victim networks and to maintain presence as they look to meet their ultimate objective of deploying MAZE ransomware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Despite these commonplace behaviors, we have observed an actor create their own domain account to enable latter-stage operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Although Mandiant has observed multiple cases where MAZE intrusion operators employed Mimikatz to collect credentials to enable privilege escalation, these efforts have also been bolstered in multiple cases via use of Bloodhound, and more manual searches for files containing credentials.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant has observed a broad range of approaches to network, host, data, and Active Directory reconnaissance across observed MAZE incidents.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The varied tools and approaches across these incidents maybe best highlights the divergent ways in which the responsible actors interact with victim networks.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Across the majority of MAZE ransomware incidents lateral movement was accomplished via Cobalt Strike BEACON and using previously harvested credentials.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Despite this uniformity, some alternative tools and approaches were also observed.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: There was evidence suggesting data exfiltration across most analyzed MAZE ransomware incidents.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: While malicious actors could monetize stolen data in various way (e.g. sale in an underground forum, fraud), actors employing MAZE are known to threaten the release of stolen data if victim organizations do not pay an extortion fee.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In addition to data theft, actors deploy MAZE ransomware to encrypt files identified on the victim network.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, the aforementioned MAZE panel has an option to specify the date on which ransom demands will double, likely to create a sense of urgency to their demands.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Based on our belief that the MAZE ransomware is distributed by multiple actors, we anticipate that the TTPs used throughout incidents associated with this ransomware will continue to vary somewhat, particularly in terms of the initial intrusion vector.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: For more comprehensive recommendations for addressing ransomware, please refer to our Ransomware Protection and Containment Strategies blog post and the linked white paper.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Organizations can validate their security controls against more than 20 MAZE-specific actions with Mandiant Security Validation.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Please see our Headline Release Content Updates – April 21, 2020 on the Mandiant Security Validation Customer Portal for more information.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant currently tracks three separate clusters of activity involved in the post-compromise distribution of MAZE ransomware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Future data collection and analysis efforts may reveal additional groups involved in intrusion activity supporting MAZE operations, or may instead allow us to collapse some of these groups into larger clusters.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: It should also be noted that ‘initial access’ phase techniques have been included in these mappings, though in some cases this access may have been provided by a separate threat actor(s).
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html
